situation: A few players are playing a boardgame. The current state of the game is as follows. The beaver has 3 dollars. The dugong has 35 dollars. The german shepherd smiles at the mouse, does not destroy the wall constructed by the reindeer, and does not swear to the worm. The rhino has 4 friends that are smart and 5 friends that are not, and has 74 dollars. And the rules of the game are as follows. Rule1: Are you certain that one of the animals is not going to swear to the worm and also does not destroy the wall built by the reindeer? Then you can also be certain that the same animal is never going to smile at the ant. Rule2: From observing that one animal smiles at the mouse, one can conclude that it also smiles at the ant, undoubtedly. Rule3: The rhino will not acquire a photograph of the ant if it (the rhino) has more money than the dugong and the beaver combined. Rule4: The rhino will not acquire a photograph of the ant if it (the rhino) has fewer than 8 friends. Rule5: The ant does not swim in the pool next to the house of the duck whenever at least one animal leaves the houses that are occupied by the pelikan. Rule6: In order to conclude that the ant swims inside the pool located besides the house of the duck, two pieces of evidence are required: firstly the german shepherd should smile at the ant and secondly the rhino should not acquire a photo of the ant. Rule2 is preferred over Rule1. Rule5 is preferred over Rule6.
question: Based on the game state and the rules and preferences, does the ant swim in the pool next to the house of the duck?
label: proved
